abstract.label: Abstract
abstract.value: Israel Amter (1881-1954) was an official in the Communist Party, USA who had studied music at the Leipzig Conservatory, where in 1912 he composed a never-performed opera, Winona, which concerns the love between a U.S. army officer and a Native American woman, Winona.

p.value: Open for research without restrictions, however, patrons must use photocopy.

Published citations should take the following form: 
                <lb/>
                <lb/>Identification of item, date; Collection name; Collection number; box number; folder number; 
                <lb/>Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives 
                <lb/>Elmer Holmes Bobst Library 
                <lb/>70 Washington Square South 
                <lb/>New York, NY 10012, New York University Libraries.

Israel Amter, founding member of the Communist Party, USA and a leading functionary into the 1940s, was born on March 26, 1881, in Denver to Jewish immigrant parents. He joined the Socialist Party in 1901, and in 1903 moved to Germany where he remained until 1914, editing the German Export Review, participating in the Social Democratic Party, and studying music at the Leipzig Conservatory, where he composed his never-performed opera Winona (1912), which concerns the love between a U.S. army officer and a Native American woman, Winona.
Contains the piano score for the opera Winona, and a photocopy of the libretto (25 pages).
